## Environmental Message in "The Little Prince"

The Little Prince emphasizes environmental stewardship through its famous passage: "It is a question of discipline. When you've finished your own toilet in the morning, then it is time to attend to the toilet of your planet, just so, with the greatest care. You must see to it that you pull up regularly all the baobabs, at the very first moment when they can be distinguished from the rosebushes which they resemble so closely in their earliest youth."

## Symbolism of Baobab Trees

The baobab trees in Saint-Exupéry's story serve multiple symbolic purposes:

**Environmental Metaphor**: If recognized too late, baobabs "spread over the entire planet" with "roots go right through it," and "if the planet is too small, and if the baobabs are too many, they tear the planet apart."

**Early Action Warning**: The Little Prince warns that "when it is a matter of baobabs, that always means a catastrophe" if action is delayed, emphasizing the importance of addressing environmental problems early.

## Climate Change Connection

Recent interpretations connect the story to modern environmental concerns:

The baobab metaphor "instructs us to take actions against destructive forces as early as possible to avoid terrible consequences. It's appropriate advice for us today, considering that we've lost nine of Africa's 13 oldest baobab trees to increasing drought brought on by climate change."(no content)From an environmental perspective, "baobab trees teach us about the importance of adaptation. These trees have evolved to thrive in arid and semi-arid environments, showcasing their remarkable ability to adapt to challenging conditions. This serves as a pertinent lesson in the face of climate change, urging us to adapt and innovate in response to environmental shifts."

## Youth and Environmental Responsibility

The story specifically targets young readers with its environmental message:

The Little Prince asks for drawings "so that the children where you live can see exactly how all this is. That would be very useful to them if they were to travel some day," and the narrator directly addresses: "Children, watch out for the baobabs!"(no content)Modern educational projects use the book to "develop activities starting from the reading and understanding of the book 'The Little Prince'" focusing on "topics of great value and relevance such as those related to the respect for the environment and for our planet," having "students analyze the main environmental and social changes that have characterized our planet in recent years, focusing on the most urgent and important problems (deforestation, animal extinction, climate change, etc.)"

## Contemporary Relevance

The environmental symbolism remains relevant today: "The rose symbolizes love, creation, and prosperity, while the baobabs incarnate hatred and destruction. Nothing changed since the Little Prince first visited our planet Earth... We need to get rid of the baobabs and spend more time on our roses."

The baobab trees in "The Little Prince" thus serve as a powerful environmental allegory about the need for vigilant care of our planet, early intervention against destructive forces, and the responsibility of each generation—particularly youth—to protect Earth for the future.
